column1: When I was a child seven years old
column2: my friends on a holiday filled my pocket with coppers. I went directly to a shop where they sold toys for children
column4: being charmed with the sound of a whistle that I met by the way in the hands of another boy
column5: I voluntarily offered and gave all my money for one. I then ran home and went whistling all over the house
column7: but disturbing all the family. My brothers and sisters and cousins
column8: understanding the bargain I had made
column9: told me I had given four times as much for it as it was worth; put me in mind what good things I might have bought with the rest of the money; and laughed at me so much for my folly that I cried with vexation; and the reflection gave me more chagrin than the whistle gave me pleasure. This
column11: was afterwards of use to me
column12: the impression continuing on my mind; so that often when I was tempted to buy some unnecessary thing
column14: "Don't give too much for the whistle";' and I saved my money.
